Award.AwardTitle: Rational Design of Eco-Friendly Homogeneous Catalysis by Rhodium- and Ruthenium-Catalyzed C-H Bond Activation and Decarboxylation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Division of Chemistry supports the efforts of Professor Pinjing Zhao of North Dakota State University Fargo for catalyst development and increased mechanistic understanding of rhodium-and ruthenium-mediated carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bond activation and decarboxylation. This research project develops the [3+2] reaction of unsubstituted imines, further develops catalytic C-H alkylation of electron deficient arenes, and investigates rhodium-mediated stoichiometric and catalytic decarboxylation. A number of rhodium(I) and ruthenium(II) complexes with phosphine and N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands are isolated and characterized. The research plan is integrated with educational and outreach activities through the COINS (Career Opportunities In Natural Sciences) Program. This program encourages undergraduate and graduate students to explore various career opportunities in the natural sciences and reaches out to rural communities in the region to enhance public awareness of scientific research and career opportunities.

The NSF Division of Chemistry supports the efforts of Professor Pinjing Zhao of North Dakota State University Fargo for the development of transition metal-based homogeneous catalysts. Rational design of efficient catalytic processes relies heavily on mechanistic understanding of relevant elementary organometallic reactions. Towards this goal, Professor Zhao and his group develop metal-catalyzed coupling reactions for the efficient carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bond formations needed for the synthesis of new pharmaceuticals and commodity chemicals. In addition to his research, Professor Zhao initiated and leads the educational and outreach program, Career Opportunities in Natural Sciences (COINS). Through this award and the COINS Program, Professor Zhao organizes annual summer workshops for 15-20 high school students and their science teachers in rural North Dakota and western Minnesota. Students and faculty participate in discussions on the social and economic impacts of research advances, technology transfer and commercialization, and career opportunities in chemistry and other natural sciences.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit 

The development of highly efficient, selective, and mild coupling reactions is a significant task for synthetic chemists. Catalytic C-H activation and decarboxylation enables the functionalization of ubiquitous C-H bonds and carboxyl groups without pre-functionalization into organic halides or main group organometallic reagents. Thus, new catalytic methods for mild C-H activation and decarboxylation can have significant impact on eco-friendly chemical synthesis. Towards this goal, we have studied Rh- and Ru-mediated C-H bond activation and decarboxylation processes to develop several new C-C and C-N coupling reactions for convenient construction of molecular complexity from simple building blocks. Mechanistic insights into these catalytic processes also allowed us to extend the scope of our study and develop several new catalytic reactions using the Ni(0)/N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) catalyst system. In general, these catalytic processes complement the existing methods and some of them feature remarkably mild reaction conditions such as greatly reduced reaction temperatures (as low as room temperature), neutral and nonpolar reaction media, and no heavy metal salt additives. 

The observation of strong ligand effects on our catalyst systems is highly important due to the potentials of ligand-enabled control over chemoselectivity, as well as ligand modification for further catalyst development, particularly for asymmetric catalysis with chiral ligand backbones. With the synergy between mechanism study and catalyst development, results from this project are expected to enhance the fundamental knowledge on structure-reactivity correlations in organometallic chemistry.

Broader Impacts

This project has provided full or partial salary support for 7 graduate students, 2 undergraduate researchers, and 1 visiting graduate student at the home institution (NDSU). In addition, this project has provided research opportunities for 1 REU student and 1 visiting high school student for summer research via the NSF-sponsored PICNICS program. Participating students have received scientific and research training in multiple areas including organic chemistry, inorganic and organometallic chemistry, homogeneous catalysis, and physical methods for reaction mechanism studies.

This project has resulted in 5 published manuscripts at high-impact chemistry journals and 3 completed graduate dissertations (1 MS and 2 PhD degrees). Student researchers were able to disseminate their research results to the scientific community and get trained in the process of scientific writing and publication. This project has also provided support for 13 student presentations at ACS national meetings and Gordon Research Conferences including. Students were able to utilize these opportunities to advance their professional communication skills and interact with fellow scientists in the community. 

Through the active participation in various educational and outreach activities, the PI’s research group has provided exposure to modern organometallic chemistry and catalysis for REU students, visiting high school students for summer research, as well as high school students and science teachers in the local community via the COINS (Career Opportunities In Nature Sciences) outreach program that the PI has developed and was sponsored by this NSF grant. 

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2017
Modified by: Pinjing Zhao
